Award.AwardTitle: Conference: The GRC 2015 on Chloroplast Biotechnology: Reengineering Photosynthetic Organelles

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Nontechnical description of the project:
Plastids are specialized plant cellular organelles that are responsible for the process of photosynthesis that converts sun light into chemical energy. This is one of the most essential processes for sustaining life on earth. The 2015 Gordon Research Conference on Chloroplast Biotechnology will present cutting-edge fundamental and potentially applied research by an international group of scientists interested in experimental approaches to probe Chloroplast structure and function. In addition, the workshop will address how engineering and biotechnology approaches can improve the output capacity of photosynthesis. The Broader Impacts of this conference will expose students and postdocs to cutting edge interdisciplinary research, and will expand their horizon on what is novel and important in this field. It will influence how early career scientists will structure their continued education and professional development to be marketable in the "New Biology" arena. The enabling technologies and scientific advances presented at this conference are likely to lead to significant advances for addressing important societal needs.

Technical:
Generally recognized benefits of plastid engineering are: the potential for high-level protein expression from plastid transgenes; the expression of multiple genes in operons; and transgene containment in crops in which only the maternal parent inherits plastids, thereby preventing transgene flow via pollen. Applications of plastid transformation will be discussed in four general areas: (1) expression of recombinant proteins for industrial and pharmaceutical applications; (2) engineering the plastid genome to improve photosynthetic efficiency and plant productivity; (3) engineering novel metabolic pathways into chloroplasts; (4) engineering novel agronomic traits into chloroplasts for gene stacking and transgene containment.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: The Chloroplast Biotechnology Gordon Research Conference (GRC) is a newly approved, biannual conference that was held for the first time January 18 - 23, 2015, at Ventura Beach Marriott, Ventura, CA, USA. The founders of the conference are Pal Maliga (Chair), Rutgers University, Piscataway, NJ, and Ralph Bock (Vice-Chair), Max Planck Institute of Molecular Plant Physiology, Potsdam-Golm, Germany. The objective of the conference was to create a forum where advances in chloroplast genome structure and function are reviewed together with applications in agriculture, industrial biotechnology and healthcare. The focus of the meeting has been on flowering plants and microalgae, but photosynthetic bacteria also have been covered as long as they provide a useful template for applications in crops. Speakers provided an update on all aspects of chloroplast gene expression. Emphasis has been on the role of nuclear-encoded, organelle-targeted RNA-binding proteins, the functions of which are largely unknown. Applications included engineering plastid-encoded genes to improve plant productivity and boost biofuel production. As exciting examples for new synthetic biology approaches, the introduction of novel biosynthetic pathways into the plastid genome through engineering synthetic polycistronic operons has been reported. Other conference highlights were the engineering of complex chloroplast-localized processes such as conversion of C3 to C4 photosynthesis and engineering nitrogen fixation into crops by engineering chloroplast and nuclear genes. Production of vaccines, industrial enzymes, and human therapeutic proteins in chloroplasts were discussed. Plastid engineering is routine in a handful of crops. Technical advances needed to extend the technology to new crops and developments of new regulated expression systems were part of the program. The Chloroplast Biotechnology GRC intends to maintain an international scope, reflected in the choice of alternating chairs from the US and abroad. In this spirit, Ralph Bock (Chair, Germany) and Maureen Hanson (Vice-Chair, USA) will organize the 2nd Chloroplast Biotechnology GRC scheduled for January 8-13, 2017, at the Ventura Beach Marriott, Ventura, CA.

Broader Impact: Because of their small size, GRCs are an excellent opportunity for intense networking and for students and postdocs to meet senior investigators and discuss their research with them. The Chloroplast Biotechnology GRC clearly achieved this goal, reflected in the favorable comments in the Conference Evaluation sheets. The conference provided an excellent opportunity for information exchange for researchers from public research institutions as well as the biotechnology industries. This intense interaction is an environment that is likely to spawn new ideas, research strategies, and ultimately commercial products. As to metrics, 98 participants attended the 1st Chloroplast Biotechnology GRC: 88.2% of the participants were affiliated with academic institutions, 9.2% with industry and 2.6% with government. Most participants from academia were professors (36.4%), postdoctoral scientists (23.4%) and graduate students (14.3%). We welcomed a surprisingly high participation from industry players, including the major US agricultural biotechnology companies (Monsanto, Bayer Crop Science, DuPont, J.R. Simplot), companies involved in biotech R&D (Agrisera, Synthetic Genomics, Reliance Industries) and national research organizations represented by USDA, Agriculture and Agri-Food Canada, CNRS (France) and Rothamsted Research (UK).
